title: The Heimlich Maneuver: How to Help a Choking Child Breathe

steps.title: See if the toddler can speak.
steps.content: See if the toddler can speak. When someone is choking, they'll lose the ability to speak because air can't get through. Therefore, if you ask the toddler a question and they can't reply, they may be choking. [1] X Research source The toddler might also grab at their throat if they are choking.

steps.title: Look to see if the toddler is having trouble breathing.
steps.content: Look to see if the toddler is having trouble breathing. You may notice that they’re having trouble drawing breaths. They may also be making weird noises when they’re breathing. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source For example, they might make a high-pitched noise when drawing in a breath. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Check for weak coughing.
steps.content: Check for weak coughing. The toddler may be trying to cough up what's in their throat and failing. Therefore, the cough will be weak. A heavy cough likely indicates that enough air is getting through that they’re not choking. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Keep an eye out for blue tinges.
steps.content: Keep an eye out for blue tinges. Toddlers who aren't breathing may start turning blue around the edges. For instance, you may notice bluish or dusky tinges on their fingernails, lips, or skin. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source However, be aware that children and toddlers compensate for a lack of oxygen better than adults and may not turn blue as fast as an adult would.

steps.title: Avoid intervening if the child is able to speak.
steps.content: Avoid intervening if the child is able to speak. If the child is able to speak or breathe well, don't start the Heimlich maneuver. The same goes if the child is able to cough hard. However, keep watching to make sure the symptoms don't suddenly worsen. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Make sure the toddler is conscious.
steps.content: Make sure the toddler is conscious. Choking can cause a toddler to pass out. See if they can look at you when you talk by asking them a question or saying their name. You'll likely need this information when you call 911 or your local emergency number. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You'll also need to move on to the steps for an unconscious choking toddler if they’re not conscious. You can also lightly flick the bottom of a toddler's foot to check for consciousness.

steps.title: Ask someone to call emergency services.
steps.content: Ask someone to call emergency services . If you are not alone with the child, ask someone to call 911 or your local emergency number. If you are alone, try the Heimlich maneuver before calling 911. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Get consent from a parent before trying the Heimlich maneuver.
steps.content: Get consent from a parent before trying the Heimlich maneuver. If the choking toddler isn’t your child, try to get consent before you attempt a rescue if possible. If a parent is present, quickly ask for consent. But remember, seconds count when saving a life! If nobody is around to ask, don’t wait. If you live in the U.S., Good Samaritan laws in your state should cover any action you take in good faith to save the child's life.

steps.title: Bend the child over at the waist.
steps.content: Bend the child over at the waist. Have the child bend over at the waist. Place your hand under their chest for support. To perform this maneuver properly on a child, you'll likely need to kneel on the floor. [9] X Research source Don't try to pull the object out of the child's mouth if the child is conscious. Try to get it out with the Heimlich maneuver instead. [10] X Research source You can also place a child across your lap face down, if that is more feasible. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Give 5 back blows.
steps.content: Give 5 back blows. Use the heel of your hand. Whack the child on the back directly between the shoulder blades 5 times. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source These blows should be fairly hard. They shouldn't be hard enough to knock the child over with your support, but they do need to be relatively sharp. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The American Heart Association doesn't teach back blows when performing the Heimlich; the Heimlich alone (abdominal thrusts) can be effective without them. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Look to see if the object has dislodged. You may see the object fly out, or you may notice the child has started breathing again. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Place your fist under the child’s breastbone.
steps.content: Place your fist under the child’s breastbone. Put your arms around the child. Use one hand to make a fist and place it directly above the child's navel. Try to get below the breastbone. Cover your fist with your other hand. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Thrust your fist upward.
steps.content: Thrust your fist upward. Pull your fist upward into the child's abdomen. Make this thrust quickly. Repeat the thrust 4 times or until you notice that the object choking the child dislodges. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Call 911 after completing the maneuver once.
steps.content: Call 911 after completing the maneuver once. If no one is around and you've tried the Heimlich once, be sure to call 911 or your local emergency services number. You want help to be on the way. If you asked someone else to call 911, make sure the person has done it.

steps.title: Check to see if it worked.
steps.content: Check to see if it worked. If the Heimlich maneuver didn't work, continue going between back blows and abdominal thrusts. Keep going until you see the object come out, the child begins to breathe normally again, or the child becomes unconscious. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Lay the child on the floor.
steps.content: Lay the child on the floor. Once the child loses consciousness, place them on the floor on their back. They should be on a flat, hard surface. Make sure to do so gently. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Call emergency services immediately.
steps.content: Call emergency services immediately. Before you do anything else, call emergency services. The sooner you can get professional medical help, the better. [20] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source If someone else is with you, ask them to call 911 or your local emergency number. That way, you can start doing CPR immediately. If you’re by yourself, put your phone on speaker so you can have your hands free to help the choking toddler.

steps.title: Check for an object in their mouth.
steps.content: Check for an object in their mouth. Do a sweep of the child's mouth with your finger. Gently tilt their head to the side and open their mouth, then look inside. If you see an object that is obviously loose in the child’s mouth (and not stuck in their throat), use your finger to carefully sweep it out of their mouth. Never try to grab or sweep out an object that is stuck or lodged in the child’s throat! [21] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Only try to remove the object if it's loose; if it's stuck in the child's throat, don't try to move it, as you can push it further down.

steps.title: Try 2 rescue breaths.
steps.content: Try 2 rescue breaths. Tilt the child's head back to open up the airway by lifting the chin. Hold their nose so air can't escape. Cover their mouth with your mouth and blow air in twice, blowing for about a second each time. Watch their chest to see if it rises. If it doesn't, move on to chest compressions. If you're having trouble pinching their nose and covering their mouth with yours, you can try to cover their nose and mouth with your mouth.

steps.title: Use chest compressions.
steps.content: Use chest compressions. Find the correct place by feeling where the bottom of the ribs meet. You should be about 1 inch (2.5 cm) above that on the child's chest. Put one hand on top of the other, flat on the chest. The heel of your hand should be in the center of the child's chest. Push the chest about 1/3 of the way down depth-wise, or about 2 inches (5.1 cm). Try to go quickly; you should be aiming for 100 compressions a minute. Count to 30 compressions. [22] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Check for an object again.
steps.content: Check for an object again. Your chest compressions could have dislodged the object that was choking the child. Open their mouth and look. Use your finger to sweep out any loose object, but don't try to move the object if it's still stuck. Check to see if the child is breathing by watching their chest.

steps.title: Continue with CPR until the child starts breathing or help arrives.
steps.content: Continue with CPR until the child starts breathing or help arrives. Continue switching between 2 rescue breaths and 30 chest compressions, checking for an object in the mouth in between. Always remember to tilt the child's chin up for the rescue breaths. Keep going until the child's condition changes or help arrives to take over. [23] X Research source Do your best to keep interruptions to a minimum while you do CPR, since keeping the compressions going will help maintain circulation. If another person is with you who can do CPR, ask for their help, since 2-person CPR is usually more effective.

steps.title: Seek immediate medical attention.
steps.content: Seek immediate medical attention. Even once the child has recovered, take them to the doctor anyway. You want to make sure they haven’t suffered any permanent damage from either the choking or the CPR.
